channel.title: What to do?
channel.description: So some guy donated to my server, got all of his items, but I guess didn't follow the rules. He got ip banned, ip muted, and jailed. Now he's raging at me, I didn't do anything, and is threatening to go to court for his $170 or something and wants it back. So what should I do? Now he's saying I'm "stealing" his money.

item.title: What to do?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

reyx7:

Ahaha $170? What the love is wrong with kids day. Enjoy your money OP, It’s called a donation for a reason.

Donation for items is in reality not a donation. Donation is when you don’t expect anything back (To charity).

Read full topic

item.title: What to do?
item.dc:creator: @sageofmali sageofmali
item.description:
@sageofmali wrote:

I got him to stop bugging me, I just don’t want fags like this doing this anymore. I haven’t linked my bank account yet

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Put the money into your bank asap before he even makes a claim

item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

He’s just mad that he already lost his money from Christmas.

item.title: What to do?
item.dc:creator: @sageofmali sageofmali
item.description:
@sageofmali wrote:

So basically all I have to do is state that it was a virtual item that he donated for?

Read full topic

item.title: What to do?
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

sageofmali:

Alright cool. Now, if he opens a dispute with paypal, which has happened to me before, how do I win the case? Because someone received their donation one time and then refunded their money and still took the items, and I didn’t know what to say. All I did was like show that he received the items, but I didn’t know how to do it the right way. Any advice?

asshole_rule:

you won’t win, the sender always wins, especially in this case (virtual items)

actually you are incorrect. albeit this was quite some time ago and i do not know whether this concept still applies to the present day as paypal may have updated its policy regarding this issue anytime in the last year (i have never actually looked at its written policy and therefore i can only make my statements based on my experience and past dispute history of 80% of charge-backs won which in my opinion is fairly decent), it might still apply; you could read the terms of service if you like. however, it essentially did not cover virtual goods in its buyer protection system which is how i (as a seller) won most of my charge-backs. it’s a great measure in my opinion because paypal unfortunately usually favors the buyer to the seller.

here was an example of a charge-back i won:

----------------------------------------------------------------------
This Claim is Now Closed

Dear ___,

We completed our investigation for the following claim:

Buyer’s name: ___
Buyer’s email: ___
Transaction ID: ___

Transaction date: Apr 21, 2012
Transaction amount: $95.00 USD
Your transaction ID: 4___
Case number: ___

Refund amount: $0.00 USD

We are denying your buyer’s claim because the item you sold was virtual,
digital, or intangible, which is not covered under PayPal Purchase
Protection. We only cover claims involving physical items that can be
shipped and tracked.

Sincerely,
PayPal

(in-case you are perplexed at why refund amount is zero, it’s actually a separate monetary transaction)

nonetheless, take every word i said with a grain of salt; read paypal’s terms of service for yourself and figure out a way you can sell your goods whose sales and evidence cannot be tracked.

Read full topic

item.title: What to do?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

sageofmali:

Damn, there is nothing I can do?

You could threaten to kill him, but that is illegal and we are not supportive of that on this forum.

@asshole_rule wrote:

i’d give him 1 more chance cause im not a douche.

but no, he can’t really get the money back unless he disputes via paypal. He can’t take you to court, lol.
